raw_text:
Apple iPod family expands market
 
 Apple has expanded its iPod family with the release of its next generation of the digital music players.
 
 Its latest challenges to the growing digital music gadget market include an iPod mini model which can hold 6GB compared to a previous 4GB. The company, which hopes to keep its dominant place in the digital music market, also said the gold coloured version of the mini would be dropped. A 30GB version has also been added to the iPod Photo family. The latest models have a longer battery life and their prices have been cut by an average of £40. The original iPod took an early lead in the digital music player market thanks to its large storage capacity and simple design.
 
 During 2004 about 25 million portable players were sold, 10 million of which were Apple iPods. But analysts agree that the success is also down to its integration with the iTunes online store, which has given the company a 70% share of the legal download music market. Mike McGuire, a research director at analyst Gartner, told the BBC News website that Apple had done a good job in "sealing off the market from competition" so far. "They have created a very seamless package which I think is the idea of the product - the design, function and the software are very impressive," he said. He added that the threat from others was always present, however. "Creative, other Microsoft-partnered devices, Real, Sony and so on, are ratcheting up the marketing message and advertising," he said. Creative was very upbeat about how many of its Creative Zen players it had shipped by the end of last year, he said. Its second-generation models, like the Creative Zen Micro Photo, is due out in the summer. It will have 5GB of memory on board.
 
 Digital music players are now the gadget of choice among young Americans, according to recent research by the Pew Internet and American Life Project. One in 10 US adults - 22 million people - now owns a digital music player of some sort. Sales of legally downloaded songs also rose more than tenfold in 2004, according to the record industry, with 200 million tracks bought online in the US and Europe in 12 months. The IFPI industry body said that the popularity of portable music players was behind the growth. Analysts say that the ease of use and growth of music services available on the net will continue to drive the trend towards portable music players.
 
 People are also starting to use them in novel ways. Some are combining automatic syncing functions many of them have with other net functions to automatically distribute DIY radio shows, called podcasts. But 2005 will also see more competition from mobile phone operators who are keen to offer streaming services on much more powerful and sophisticated handsets. According to Mr McGuire, research suggests that people like the idea of building up huge libraries of music, which they can do with high-capacity storage devices, like iPods and Creative Zens. Mobiles do not yet have this capacity though, and there are issues about the ease of portability of mobile music. Mr McGuire said Apple was ensuring it kept a foot in the mobile music door with its recent deal with Motorola to produce a version of iTunes for Motorola phones.
llama3.2:1b: Apple has released new iPod models that expand its market share in the digital music player industry.
The latest models include an 80GB model and a 30GB model, which are cheaper than their predecessors by £40.
Apple also plans to drop the gold coloured mini version of the iPod mini due to low sales.
llama3.2:3b: Apple has expanded its iPod family with new models that include an iPod mini with 6GB storage, a 30GB iPod Photo model, and dropped gold-colored versions.
The latest models have improved battery life and lower prices.
Apple's integration with the iTunes online store has helped it dominate the digital music market, but competitors like Creative and Microsoft are increasing their marketing efforts.
Digital music players have become popular among young Americans, with one in ten US adults owning a device, and sales of downloaded songs have risen over tenfold in 2004.
gemma2:2b: Apple has released new iPod models with increased storage capacity (6GB mini), extended battery life, and lower prices.
The company is maintaining its dominance in the digital music market through integration with the iTunes store and seamless user experience.
Competition from devices like Creative's Zen line and mobile phone operators offering streaming services is emerging.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Apple has expanded its iPod family by introducing a 30GB model, dropping the gold-coloured mini and adding a 25 million portable player sales figure.
The latest models have improved battery life and prices while also incorporating an online store to seal off competition from other players in the digital music market.

Digital music players continue to be popular among young Americans, with one in ten adults owning some form of portable music device as of 2007 according to recent research by the Pew Internet and American Life Project.
Mobile phones are expected to play an increasing role in portable music devices and will likely see competition from more powerful handsets like Motorola's version of iTunes for their phones.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Apple expands iPod lineup by introducing a 6GB mini model, drops gold version, adds 30GB iPod Photo, increases battery life and price reductions.
Its digital music player strategy is effective due to integration with iTunes and market monopoly.
Young Americans increasingly prefer portable music players; sales of legally downloaded songs nearly doubled in 2004.
Competition from mobile phone operators will increase in 2005 as users look for storage capacity on handsets.
qwen2.5:3b: Apple has expanded its iPod family by releasing new models with enhanced storage (6GB vs 4GB), longer battery life, and lower prices (£40 avg reduction).
The gold version is discontinued, while a 30GB model is added to the iPod Photo line.
Apple aims to maintain dominance in digital music players through integration with iTunes, which holds a 70% share of legal downloads.
Competition from devices like Creative Zen suggests Apple must continue to innovate and market its products effectively.
Digital music players are popular among young Americans, driven by convenience and growing online services.
The trend is expected to see increased competition from mobile phone operators offering streaming services on more advanced handsets.
opencoder:1.5b:
Apple iPod family has expanded market

The company has released its next generation digital music players, expanding its iPod family's dominance in the gadget market.
The latest challenges include an iPod mini model capable of holding 6GB compared to a previous 4GB storage capacity.
The company also said the gold coloured mini model would be dropped due to price points.
A 30GB version has been added to the iPod Photo family, which has offered a substantial increase in sales compared to its earlier 10GB models.
The latest models have longer battery life and are priced by an average of £40 less than the original iPod.
Apple's digital music players have been seen as the dominant player in the market, reflecting a steady growth pattern that keeps up with increasing competition from other brands.
The integration with iTunes has contributed to its dominance.
In recent years, people are starting to see the use of these devices for novel and more complex ways, such as syncing automatic functions with other internet functions.
Nevertheless, 2005 remains a significant competitive year in which sales have risen more than 10 fold.
Research from the Pew Internet and American Life Project suggests that users appreciate the ease of building up large libraries of music, and the capability for high-capacity storage devices.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Apple has expanded its iPod family by introducing the 6GB Mini model and a phased removal of the gold Mini version.
They also released a new 30GB Photo music player.
The latest models have improved battery life and lower prices compared to previous generations.
Apple's integration with iTunes enhances their market presence, securing a significant share in the legal download music market.
Research shows digital music players are popular among young Americans, owning around 22 million of them globally.
Sales of downloaded songs surged by tenfold in 2004, reaching 200 million tracks.
The trend towards portable devices and user innovations like podcasts highlight increased interest.
Mobile operators are competing with Apple for smart handsets, while Apple is collaborating on a Motorola version of iTunes to maintain its market presence.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Apple iPod family has expanded its market, including the release of a new generation of the portable players and the addition of an iPod mini model that can hold 6GB compared to previous models' 4GB.

The company also dropped the gold version of the iPod Photography model from its lineup in favor of a longer-lasting battery life with an average reduction of £40 for its original iPod, which has become a key player in the digital music market since its release in 2004.

The popularity of portable music players, such as the Creative ZeNs and Digital Player 3 by the Peer Internet and American Life Project, is driving the growth of these devices, with a predicted tenfold rise in online legally downloaded songs.
This has led to an increase in the number of users who are combining automatic syncing functions of many digital music players with other net services like DIY radio shows called podcasts.
However, mobile phone operators also face competition from mobile music devices that have high-capacity storage devices, like iPod models, as well as issues about ease of portability of mobile music.
Apple has ensured a foot in the mobile music door by producing a version of iTuNes for Motorola phone users.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Apple has expanded its iPod family with the release of its next generation of the digital music players, offering users even more storage capacity and improved battery life.
The company also announced that the gold-coloured version of the mini will be dropped from its lineup, while a 30GB version will join the already available iPod Photo family.
The new models have longer battery lives than their predecessors and are now available with a lower price tag.
Analysts believe Apple's integration of its popular iTunes online store is to blame for the increased popularity of digital music players among young Americans.

According to Gartner Research's Mike McGuire, there will be more competition in the market from devices like Creative Zens and Microsoft's Creative Zen Micro Photo, which offer 5GB of memory on board.
These advancements in technology have led to increased usage of digital music players by a younger demographic, creating an increasingly competitive market for portable music players.

A 30GB version of the Mini Photo was also added to the iPod Photo family.
The latest models have longer battery life and lower prices.
While the iPhone led in the market with its large storage capacity and simple design, the integration with the iTunes online store gave Apple 70% of the legal download music market share.
Other companies like Creative and Sony are responding by releasing their own digital music players.
Portable music players are now the gadget of choice among young Americans, according to recent research, with 22 million people owning one in 2004.
Sales of legally downloaded songs also increased tenfold that year, thanks to the ease of use and growth of music services available on the net.
While mobile phones may offer streaming services, portable music players remain popular for building up huge libraries of music.

The company has also discontinued the gold-colored version of the mini.
Additionally, a 30GB version has been added to the iPod Photo family.
The latest models have longer battery life and their prices have been cut by an average of £40.
The original iPod took an early lead in the digital music player market thanks to its large storage capacity and simple design.
During 2004, about 25 million portable players were sold, with 10 million of them being Apple iPods.
The success of the company is also down to its integration with the iTunes online store, which has given it a 70% share of the legal download music market.
Creative was very upbeat about its second-generation models, including the Creative Zen Micro Photo, which will have 5GB of memory on board.

Mobile phone operators are also expected to offer more streaming services on more powerful and sophisticated handsets in 2005, but analysts say that people like the idea of building up huge libraries of music, which they can do with high-capacity storage devices, like iPods and Creative Zens.
Apple is ensuring it keeps a foot in the mobile music door with its recent deal with Motorola to produce a version of iTunes for Motorola phones.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Apple has introduced new iterations to its iPod family, including an iPod mini with 6GB storage and a 30GB iPod Photo model.
These devices offer enhanced battery life and reduced prices by £40 on average compared to their predecessors.
Apple aims to maintain its dominance in the digital music market, where it accounts for about 70% of legal downloads through the iTunes store.
Analysts acknowledge Apple's success due to its seamless integration of hardware, software, and online services.
Competition is intensifying from companies like Creative, Microsoft-partnered devices, Real, Sony, and upcoming models such as the Creative Zen Micro Photo (5GB).
According to recent research, one in ten US adults owns a digital music player, with sales of legally downloaded songs increasing over 10 times from 2004.
The popularity of portable players is driving this growth due to their ease of use and growing online music services.
Consumers are also leveraging these devices for automatic syncing and creating podcasts.
In 2005, competition will intensify as mobile phone operators introduce streaming services on more advanced handsets.
Despite this, Apple is preparing for the mobile market by partnering with Motorola to provide iTunes functionality on their phones.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Apple has expanded its iPod family with new models, including a 6GB iPod mini and a 30GB iPod Photo, while discontinuing the gold-colored mini.
The latest models feature longer battery life and lower prices.
Apple maintains dominance in the digital music market, selling 10 million iPods in 2004, aided by seamless integration with iTunes, which holds a 70% share of the legal download market.
Competitors like Creative, Sony, and Microsoft-partnered devices are increasing their marketing efforts, with Creative launching new models.
Digital music players are increasingly popular, with 22 million US adults owning one, and legal music downloads rising significantly.
The trend is driven by ease of use and growing online music services.
Emerging trends include podcasting and competition from mobile phones offering streaming services, though storage limitations remain a challenge.
Apple is addressing this by partnering with Motorola to bring iTunes to mobile phones.
